privacyLaws.description: The Act delineates a consumer’s personal data rights and provides that residents of this State will have the right to know what information is being collected about them, see the information, correct any inaccuracies, or request deletion of their personal data that is being maintained by entities or people.

personalDataCategories: Mental or physical health condition or diagnosis (including pregnancy)
Personal data of a known child

individualRights.name: Right to Know if a controller is processing the consumer’s personal information
Right to Obtain a List of Categories of Third Partes to which the controller disclosed the personal information
Right to Opt Out of Targeted Advertising, Sale of Personal information, or Automated Profiling

notice.description: A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear, and meaningful privacy notice that includes six key components. Firstly, it should outline the categories of personal data that the controller processes. Secondly, it must clarify the purpose for which personal data is being processed. Thirdly, it should elucidate how consumers can exercise their rights, including the process for appealing a decision made by the controller regarding their request. Fourthly, the notice should specify the categories of personal data that the controller shares with third parties, if any. Fifthly, it must disclose the categories of third parties with whom the controller shares personal data, if applicable. Lastly, the notice must provide an active electronic mail address or another online mechanism through which consumers can contact the controller for inquiries or concerns regarding their personal data.

purposeLimitation.description: Except as otherwise permitted by this chapter, not process personal data for purposes that are neither reasonably necessary to, nor compatible with, the disclosed purposes for which such personal data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer, unless the controller obtains the consumer’s consent.

dataMinimization.description: Limit the collection of personal data to what is adequate, relevant, and reasonably necessary in relation to the purposes for which such data is processed, as disclosed to the consumer.

securityReqs.description: Establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: Processors must adhere to several requirements. Firstly, they must implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to assist controllers in responding to consumer rights requests. Secondly, processors are tasked with aiding controllers in ensuring the security of processing personal data and in notifying the controller of any breaches of security. Thirdly, processors must provide necessary information to enable controllers to conduct and document data protection assessments. Additionally, contracts between controllers and processors must govern the data processing procedures, outlining instructions for processing data, the nature and purpose of processing, the type of data subject to processing, and the duration of processing. Furthermore, processors must ensure confidentiality, delete or return personal data to the controller upon request, provide information to demonstrate compliance with obligations, engage subcontractors as per controller's direction, and allow for assessments of their compliance.

riskImpact.description: A controller that manages or handles the data of at least 100,000 consumers, excluding data specifically processed for payment transactions, is required to conduct and document regular data protection assessments for each processing activity that poses an elevated risk of harm to consumers. These assessments are necessary for activities such as processing data for targeted advertising, selling personal data, or conducting profiling that could lead to unfair treatment or unlawful discrimination against consumers.

dataTransfer.description: Sale of personal data does not include the disclosure or transfer of personal data to an affiliate of the controller or The disclosure or transfer of personal data to a third party as an asset that is part of a merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other similar transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller’s assets, or a proposed merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other similar transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller’s assets.

exemptions.description: Non-profit organizations dedicated exclusively to preventing and addressing insurance crime
Financial institution or an affiliate of a financial institution governed by, or personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with the GLBA
Covered entity or business associate as defined in the privacy regulations of HIPAA
National securities associations registered under Section 15A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and registered futures associations designated under Section 17 of the Commodity Exchange Act.

nonProfitsCovered: Not all nonprofit organization are exempt
preemption: Personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in relation to price, route, or service, as such terms are used in the Airline Deregulation Act, 49 U.S.C. § 40101, et seq., as amended, by an air carrier subject to said act, to the extent any part of this chapter is preempted by the Airline Deregulation Act, 49 U.S.C. § 41713, as amended.

penalties: Fines and penalties may reach as high as $10,000 for each violation.
privateRightOfAction: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as providing the basis for, or be subject to, a private right of action for violations of said sections or any other law.

threshold.description: Control or process the personal information of no less than 35,000 consumers (excluding personal information processed solely for completing payment transactions).
Control or process the personal data of no less than 10,000 consumers and derive more than 20% of your gross annual revenue from the sale of personal data.

privacyLaws.lawName: Chapter 12C, Online and Personal Privacy Protection
privacyLaws.description: This chapter establishes regulations and requirements aimed at protecting the privacy of individuals using commercial internet websites, online services, applications, and mobile applications.

privacyLaws.lawName: Chapter 81A, Student Data Privacy Protection Act
privacyLaws.description: This chpater aims to safeguard the privacy of student data collected and used by educational institutions and third-party operators providing services to K-12 schools.
This Act seeks to strengthen data security practices and ensure timely notification of security breaches to affected individuals.
